description: Let G = complete graph on 4 vertices, create the sequence G, L(G), L(L(G)), L(L(L(G))), ... where each graph in this sequence is the line graph of the previous graph; a(n) is number of vertices of the n-th graph in this sequence.
comments: If G is k-regular, then L(G) is (2k-2)-regular. From this it is easy to get the formula for a(n).
formula: a(0)=4 and for n >= 1 a(n) = 4 * product k=1...n (1+2^(k-2))
example: The line graph of the complete graph on 4 vertices has C(4,2) vertices so a(1) = 6.
maple: for n from 0 to 30 do printf(`%d,`,4*product(1+2^(k-2), k=1..n)) od:
